overview: From 2025-12-05 to 2025-12-06, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 7 new PRs (5 merged), 10 new issues, and 28 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Update op-node v1.16.3. EL node can’t synchronize
topIssues.author: J1a-wei
topIssues.body:
We run Optimism, Base, and Worldchain using op-geth and op-node. Today we upgraded op-node from v1.16.2 to v1.16.3, and now all three op-stack deployments can’t synchronize—the logs all show the same issue. 

```
2025-12-05T15:53:59.448752163+08:00 t=2025-12-05T07:53:59+0000 lvl=info msg="Walking back L1Block by hash" curr=0x1778fbe67edaff50fd66937a1bc84001a30675fbb49b2f9d1715534c34c684f9:23941450 next=0xc67cfd13b7484bc173f3deb0d85f9d64c0d7a1ebeaca1163572c60b43c313e66:23941449 l2block=0xace3b44d8317456b0220f81608117215ee74152a05bdfce00c64fdecd235f5c1:144637148

```

topIssues.title: Set `FeesDepositor` address on deployer upon deployment
topIssues.author: 0xDiscotech
topIssues.body:
Once the `FeesDepositor` contract is deployed on L1, its address must be hardcoded in the `l1FeesDepositor` variable in `op-deployer/pkg/deployer/standard/standard.go`. It must be also be updated on the superchain-ops repo, as the value for `l1WithdrawerRecipient` address as long as the chain integrates with this feature.

The `FeesDepositor` address won't be user-configurable because there will initially be only one contract on L1
that forwards fees to the OP network, which is why we need to hardcode it in the deployer.

Currently is set to a placeholder to avoid an error on a zero address check, but needs to be updated.

topIssues.title: challenger: Introduce supernode provider
topIssues.author: Inphi
topIssues.body: Integrate a supernode provider to eventually replace the supervisor provider. Since the supernode API isn't fully implemented yet, the challenger should continue using the supervisor provider to maintain e2e testing coverage. Ideally, we can hide both API variants behind a unified interface to make the eventual migration to supernode seamless. I suggest refactoring the `super.RootProvider` interface and the `SuperTraceProvider` to accommodate both APIs.

topIssues.title: dispute-mon: Migrate to supernode APIs
topIssues.author: Inphi
topIssues.body:
Replace supervisor API usage in dispute-mon with supernode APIs. Although the supernode API isn't fully implemented yet, there aren't e2e tests in dispute-mon that depends on a concrete implementation so it's OK to completely replace the supervisor client.

The dispute-mon config flags should be updated for supernode use.

topIssues.title: proxyd: support `eth_sendRawTransactionSync`
topIssues.author: tynes
topIssues.body:
See discussion [here](https://ethresear.ch/t/halving-transaction-submission-latency-with-eth-sendrawtransactionsync/22482), but the tldr is that this cuts the number of networking roundtrips down when submitting a transaction, decreasing the latency of tx confirmation in particular for chains that have fast blocktimes.

It has been merged into geth in https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/32830. There is viem support for this method, would be good to have strong support in OP Stack and have applications start migrating to it to decrease latency

topPRs.title: Add kona-healthcheck support to conductor
topPRs.author: teddyknox
topPRs.body:
Adds a first-class Kona health probe alongside the existing rollup-boost healthcheck.

This is necessary because kona already had a healthz endpoint defined, which is used to return the kona version, and this healthcheck protocol is incompatible with the rollup-boost healthcheck protocol.

The conductor now has a JSON-aware Kona client, wires its results through the SequencerHealthMonitor, and exposes CLI/config toggles to opt into the Kona path. Health semantics (partial tolerance, failover) reuse the existing rollup-boost flow. The configuration layer enforces that at most one of the two probes can be enabled at a time, and new unit tests cover the Kona client, monitor behavior, and config validation.

topPRs.title: ci: reduce permissions of fork builds & fix tag releases
topPRs.author: falcorocks
topPRs.body:
## Summary
Split the docker CI workflows following the infra repo pattern:

- **tags.yaml**: handles release tag pushes (GCP registry, attestation)
- **branches.yaml**: handles develop push and PRs with local/fork distinction
  - `local` job: develop push or local branch PRs → GCP registry
  - `fork` job: fork PRs → ttl.sh, minimal permissions

## Dependencies
- Depends on https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/factory/pull/9 (docker-bake fork detection)

## Changes
- Renamed `protected.yaml` → `tags.yaml` (tags only)
- Renamed `unprotected.yaml` → `branches.yaml` (branches + PRs with local/fork split)
- Fork PRs now get reduced permissions and push to ttl.sh
- Local branch PRs now get full permissions and push to GCP registry
